title: Don‚Äôt Filter‚ÄîCompare. Try This in Tableau.
author: Andy Kriebel
description:
Learn how to use Proportional Brushing in Tableau to show contribution without filtering your data.

Most dashboards rely on filters.
But sometimes your users need context, not isolation.

In this tutorial, I‚Äôll walk you step by step through how to build a proportional brushing interaction using Set Actions in Tableau.
You‚Äôll learn how to:

‚úÖ Highlight a selected value in one chart
‚úÖ Show how it contributes to a second chart
‚úÖ Keep the full dataset visible without filtering
‚úÖ Create a smooth, intuitive user experience with simple calculations

This technique is perfect for comparative dashboards, contribution analysis, and performance insights across categories.

Whether you‚Äôre building dashboards for executives, product teams, or sales leaders, this approach will help them see the full picture.

üîó Exclusive access to the workbook - https://public.tableau.com/app/profile/andy.kriebel/viz/SetActions-ProportionalBrushing_17603416371560/ProportionalBrushing

title: Create Actionable KPIs
author: Andy Kriebel
description:
Key performance indicators (KPIs) are a method of comparing goals and objectives. What do you want to achieve? How does that compare to how you are doing?

KPIs tell you if you are making progress.

Must-haves for KPIs to be effective:

1. Progress - how are we doing so far?
2. Target - what are we comparing to?
3. Status - how are we performing compared to the target?
4. Action - indicator for good or bad

Different types of key performance indicators:

‚óè Big numbers
‚óè Sparklines
‚óè Bar charts

Or combinations of all of these.

After following this video, you will know how to develop key performance indicators that track your organization's goals and objectives.

title: Clean Messy Data in Tableau in Seconds!
author: Andy Kriebel
description:
In this tutorial, I‚Äôll show you how to use Tableau‚Äôs Data Interpreter to clean up a messy dataset in seconds. You‚Äôll learn how to automatically remove unnecessary headers, fix field names, and get your data ready for analysis.

Then, we‚Äôll take that cleaned data and build a Population Pyramid from scratch ‚Äî perfect for visualizing demographic distributions like age and gender.

You‚Äôll learn:
 ‚Ä¢ How Tableau‚Äôs Data Interpreter works and when to use it
 ‚Ä¢ Tips for cleaning data quickly without leaving Tableau
 ‚Ä¢ Step-by-step instructions to create a Population Pyramid
 ‚Ä¢ How to make your visualization clear and easy to read

Whether you‚Äôre a beginner or an experienced Tableau user, this video will help you save time, clean your data, and create a chart that impresses stakeholders.

Data (from ONS) - https://www.ons.gov.uk/visualisations/dvc1914/fig4/datadownload.xlsx

title: How to Create Hexbin Scatterplots in Tableau
author: Andy Kriebel
description:
Scatterplots with tons of overlapping marks are hard to understand. Try hexbins instead! 

In this tutorial, you‚Äôll learn, step-by-step, how to create hexbin scatterplots in Tableau to better visualize dense data and uncover patterns more easily.

This method works whether you're working with latitude and longitude or simply two measures you want to compare.

This is perfect for you if you want to:
- Reduce overlapping in your scatterplots or maps
- Understand how hexbinning works

It's a really cool technique that I know you're going to be able to put to use right away!

üëâ In the comments...let me know one thing you learned.

Get the coffee chain data - https://data.world/vizwiz/coffee-chain-2041-2023

title: How to Add Two Values to One Parameter in Tableau
author: Andy Kriebel
description:
Most people think parameters can only hold one value.
But what if I told you‚Ä¶ you can hack them to hold two?

In this quick tutorial, I‚Äôll show you how to build a dynamic date range using just a single parameter... yes, really.

You‚Äôll get:

‚úÖ Step-by-step setup
‚úÖ A powerful technique few Tableau users know

How could you use this in your work? Let me know your use case in the comments.
